text:
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES.

No. 5

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

(Drawing by Richard Graburn)

Please print name and address in capital letters.

Your full name (Mrs.) Maud BUNYEE
Present Address 132 Lorne St., Swift Current
Pioneer Address Saskatchewan Landing
Year you came to Saskatchewan 1907
(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan)

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1914, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
Please print name and address in capital letters.

Your full name: (Mrs.) Maud Brunyee

Present Address: 132 Lorne St., Swift Current

Pioneer Address: Saskatchewan, Standing

Year you came to Saskatchewan: 1907

(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan.)

PLEASE NOTE:

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1914, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the Questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? 

   How many of these were bachelor's homes?

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors?

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days?

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation?

   What time of the day did you go, - in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.?

5. What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand?

6. How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (that is, was the term to "take potluck" used, or was some other expression common?)

7. If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had "dropped in"?

8. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"?

9. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity?

10. Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

11. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whist drives or dances in homes? Describe.

12. Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates.

13. Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, - every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.?
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE.

No. 5

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life,

NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? 

2. How many of these were bachelor's homes? 

3. How often did you usually visit neighbors? 

4. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? 

5. Were you often invited to other homes? 

6. What time of the day did you go, in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? 

7. What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? 

8. How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? 

9. If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had dropped in? 

10. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"? 

11. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? 

12. Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the bees were for, and how often they occurred. 

13. Were there more frequent in later years? Give dates. 

14. Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one house to another at definite times, every two weeks, once a month, once a month, etc.? 

RECEIVED MAR 22 1954 SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES REGISTRATION
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, picnics, etc., if you have not described these on the School Questionnaire). Give dates.

From 1912 the schools were used for all gatherings, also serving parties.

How much of your social life was centred around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

Being 4 miles from the school nearest, actually we did not go to the schools as often as the farmers' families nearby, but occasionally.

9. When was your first community hall built?

What material was it made of? Linoleum How large was it?

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.?

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall? County School.

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (For example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.?).

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend? Yes.

How were babies and small children provided for?

They were kept in the small chairs on top of the piano, others around.

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties?

There was always a barn at the school, so horses could be kept there to eat straw. Sometimes they were brought into the house.

11. What card games were popular in the early days?

Was there card playing for a prize? Sometimes.

What dances were popular? Fox trot, waltz, polka, two-step.

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain. No.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain. Yes, card playing was accepted.
8. Tell what was done at the school house for community dances, etc., etc.

9. How much of your social life was centered around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

10. What material was it made of? Describe.

11. Who built it? Who did the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.? Describe.

12. Has it been in the village or town, or was it a country hall? Gravity school.

13. To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (For example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.? )

14. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend?

15. How were babies and small children provided for?

16. Was there card playing for a prize? Sometimes.

17. What dances were popular? Fox-tail, waltz, polka, two-steps.

18. Was there any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

19. Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.
12. What attempts at formality, or "swank," do you remember in small towns, such as gloves and hats when calling, calling cards, visitors treated ceremonially in parlor, etc.? 

13. Was the chivaree known in your community? A military ball was given in 1912.

Describe what you remember about chivarees, telling how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc.

They used to make a big noise, until the newspapers appeared, and subsidized them by giving money or drinks.

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc., that you remember, telling of any games or amusements not already mentioned that were popular at parties and give approximate dates whenever you can when some changes in visiting or social life became noticeable.

In 1911 we all all at home days, & the adult was furnished a copy of the visiting card. Generally "Second Thursday" was the day chosen, whichever day that happened to be, as I felt that was easy to remember. And had a good house every month, neighbors didn't always wait for next to be visited—there was always someone who needed help. It was like a monthly party that all looked forward to.

ORGANIZATIONS AND MEETINGS.

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember becoming established in your community?

The Hospital Aid, & I.O.D.F.

Give the date and reason for it being organized.

In 1918 the I.O.D.F. was organized as a branch of the Red Cross during the First World War.

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers local in your community?

Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.

Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it?

How many women belonged? How often did it meet?

What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district?

When was it organized?

Approximately how many women belonged to it?

Describe what you remember of its activities and services.

Not so early.
12. What attempts at formality or "etiquette" do you remember in small towns, such as gloves and hats when calling, calling cards, etc.? 

13. Was the chivalry known in your community? It wasn't very much in Canada in 1912.

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc., that you remember.

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember being established in your community?

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers' local in your community? If so, how tall when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.

Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it?

How many women belonged?

How often did it meet?

What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district?

When was it organized?

Approximately how many women belonged to it?

Describe what you remember of its activities and services.
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1914, giving the name of each, date when it was first organized, its activities and purposes, who belonged (men, women, young people?), whether it included people only in one relatively small area (for example, within a school district), or was centred in the town or village and included the surrounding community. (There is space in the church questionnaire for organizations connected with the church, so they need not be included here).

What means were commonly used by organizations for raising money?

Having fundraising socials, concerts (amateur) fairs.

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings? In a hall.

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.? Yes in Canada, early in the.

Describe, telling who gave them (local ministers or teachers, special lecturers, etc.), where they were held, how well they were attended, and any other details you remember about them.

Did you often have magic lantern shows? Give dates if possible.

Who provided the lantern and the slides?

What were the slides about?

CHILDREN'S GAMES

21. What games did boys play in summer (-mumbletypeg, ball, marbles, fly kites, etc.)?

What games did girls play in summer (-skipping rope, play house, etc.)?
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1914, giving the name of each, date when it was formed, purpose, membership (men, women, young people only, etc.), whether it included clergymen or clergymen only. In one relatively small area (for example, within a school district) or one centered in the town or village and included the surrounding countryside, try to secure in the church questionnaire list for organizations connected with the church, employes, etc., names not included here.

What means were commonly used by organizations for raising money?

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings?

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.? If so, who gave them? (Local ministers or teachers, special lecturers, etc.) where they were held, how well they were attended, and any other details you remember about them.

Did you often have magic lantern shows? Give dates if possible.

Who provided the lantern and the slides?

What were the slides about?

CHILDREN'S GAMES

21. What games did boys play in summer (-mumbletypeg, ball, marbles, fly kites, etc.)?

What games did girls play in summer (-skipping rope, play house, etc.)?
22. What winter games were played outside - fox and hounds, skating, etc.?  
What games were played indoors in winter - card games such as "Happy Families", "Authors" or others, checkers or other games?  

Did the whole family join in such games, or only the children? Explain.  
*Just the children*

23. Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? Explain.  
*No*

24. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrowheads, gophers or other objects or animals, or games in the snow? Describe.  
*No*

**PICNICS AND SPORTS.**

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan? Give year and month if possible.  
*1908*

26. Who organized it?  
*Some people in Swift Current*

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.?  
*For everybody, as there were very few residents in 1908*

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community?  
*No*

If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?  
*No*

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)?  
*Just having a good supper, brought by the guests + sitting + talking.*

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups?  
*All together*

31. What did you have to eat and drink?  
*Salad, pickled eggs, tea, cake, etc.*

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last?  
*Started at 5 o'clock & ended at 9 P.M.*
23. What winter games were played outside - fox and hounds, skating, etc.? 

What games were played indoors in winter - card games such as Whist, Pind-

lows, "Mushers" or other, checkers or other games? 

Did the whole family join in such games, or only the children? Explain.

24. Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind

of work? Explain.

25. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrow-

heads, gorhorns or other objects or animals, or games in the snow? Describe.

PICNICS AND SPORTS.

26. Who organized it? Some began in Smith County.

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school

district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.? 

Was it held in the community?

If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?

28. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band,

etc.)? 

29. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did

families and friends form smaller groups?

30. What did you have to eat and drink? Salad, pickled eggs, etc.

31. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last? 

Started at 3 o'clock and ended at 9 PM.
33. Describe any features of this picnic which you remember as outstanding.

34. Describe any different kinds of picnics which you knew of in the early days; such as the large community picnic, school or Sunday School picnics, family picnics, etc. Tell about any differences in numbers attending, activities, food and drink, when held, etc.

35. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

Now, people go with their families only, or a few close friends. Numbers in the population is now 7000.

36. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (men, women, mostly young people). Basketball, softball, etc., were played.

37. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

What year? How long did it continue?

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, giving date of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities - played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centres, etc.

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.). Never had an outdoor rink.

When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for?

About 1910, skating & curling rink.
33. Describe any features of this place which you remember as outstanding.

34. Describe any different kinds of places which you knew of in the early days; such as the large community places, school or Sunday School, Picnics, family, pool hall, etc., tell about any differences in numbers attending, activities, food and drinks, when held, etc.

35. What changes have you noticed in places since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

36. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (men, women, mostly young people).

37. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

What year?

How long did it continue?

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, giving date of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities - played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centres, etc.

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.). When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for?

About 1910, skating & curling.
7.

Q. When did an annual "sports day" become established in your community? From 1907
Did it grow out of or replace the earlier community picnic?
Who was responsible for starting the first sports day? The Town

When was the sports day usually held? (what month, or any special day, such as May 24th or July 1st). July 1st

41. Are there any from your community who have become members of well-known hockey, ball or other teams? Give names, and dates.
Yes, but I don't know them.

READING

42. What books did you bring with you when you came west? (Give a list of the names and authors if possible. If not, tell as nearly as you can how many books you brought, and what kind.) (Use extra sheets if necessary)
Shakespeare (bound volume) Can't remember but not very many.

43. How many of your neighbors brought books with them?
What kind of books and how many?

44. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors? No

45. Did you buy many books after you came west? Give details. Not many

46. What books were sent to you as gifts in early years?
Novels mostly

47. Have you ever had any "travelling library" books in your community or school? Give details and dates.
Yes

8. Was there a school library? Yes When was it begun? 1925
To what extent were books borrowed from the school library for adults to read at home? No

49. Did parents ever use their children's school text books as additional reading material? No
7.

40. When did an annual "sports day" become established in your community? From 1907

Did it grow out of or replace the earlier community picnic?

Who was responsible for starting the first sports day? Mr. Loring

Then was the sports day usually held (what month, or any special day, such as May 24th or July 4th)? July 4th

41. Are there any from your community who have become members of well-known hockey, ball or other teams? Yes, Jack and Norma

READING

42. What books did you bring with you when you came west? (Give a list of the names and authors, if possible. If not, tell as nearly as you can how many books you brought, and what kind.) (Use extra sheets if necessary)

Shakespeare (borrowed at home) (Can't remember)

not so very many

43. How many of your neighbors brought books with them?

What kind of books and how many?

44. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors?

45. Did you buy many books after you came west? Give details. Not many

46. What books were sent to you as gifts in early years?

47. Have you ever had any "travelling library" books in your community or school? Give details and dates.

8. Was there a school library? Yes

When was it begun? 1925

To what extent were books borrowed from the school library for adults to read at home?

49. Did parents ever use their children's school text books as additional reading material? Yes
50. Has there ever been a community library in your district or town?
   When was it started? 1918
   Who started it? Public Library
   Is it still in existence? Yes
   If not, when was it discontinued, and why?

Give any other details which you can about the library - how many books it contained, how many people used it, where it was kept, who acted as librarian, and what arrangements were made for borrowing books.

It is now kept in the Collegiate, a large library, very good, new books often bought. A skilled librarian is employed, University man.

51. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to the west?
   The local "Sun"

52. Describe later changes in your subscriptions, telling why you stopped certain subscriptions and added others.

53. Did you ever obtain the free monthly Lady Aberdeen packages of reading material?
   No
   Give dates and tell how and where you got them.

54. What books or papers that you brought to the west with you do you still have?

55. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your early days in the west a hardship? Explain.
   There were no bookstores near here, then books only at drug stores.
50. Has there ever been a community library in your district or town? Yes.

When was it started? 1918

Is it still in existence? Yes

If not, when was it discontinued, and why?

Give any other details which you can about the library - how many books it contained, how many people used it, where it was kept, who acted as librarian, and what arrangements were made for borrowing books.

It is now kept at the College, a large library, a very good, new house, the library is employed, University-area.

51. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to the west?

To local "Sun"

52. Describe later changes in your subscriptions, telling why you stopped certain subscriptions and added others.

53. Did you ever obtain the free monthly Lord Atholian packages of reading material?

Give dates and tell how and where you got them.

54. What books or papers that you brought to the west with you do you still have?

55. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your early days in the west a hardship? Explain.

Books for new hire, New Sale only at any store.
MUSICAL ENTERTAINMENT.

56. What musical instruments did you bring west with you? None

57. What instruments did any of your neighbors have? None

58. What musical instruments have you bought since you came to the west? Give dates, prices if possible, and tell where you bought them.

A piano in 1907. It was shipped from Kansas.

59. How large a part did singing and other forms of music play in your home entertainment in early years in the West? Describe.

Singing or playing piano every night.

in the community? (were there musical concerts, was there group singing at parties, etc.) Describe. No

60. What were some of the favorite songs in the home?

Little piggy came in the rain, A long way from home, etc. When a boy was published.

in the community?

61. Was "folk music", or music of the country you came from, popular in your home or community? Explain. No

62. Did you ever make up any of your own songs, or make up words to fit an old tune as a joke on somebody, or because of some special happening in the community? Explain. No

63. Was there a band in your community? No When was it started?

Who started it? How long did it continue?

How many were in it? Who was bandmaster?

What instruments were included?

Tell what you remember of its activities, how often practice was held, where, if members had uniforms, what events the band played for.
Musical Instruments

56. What musical instruments did you bring west with you?

57. What instruments did any of your neighbors have?

58. What musical instruments have you bought since you came to the west? Give dates, prices if possible, and tell where you bought them.

59. How large a part did singing and other forms of music play in your house entertainment in early years in the West? Describe.

In the community? (more than musical concerts, was there group singing at parties, etc.) Describe.

60. What were some of the favorite songs in the home?

61. Was "folk music", or music of the country you came from, popular in your home or community? Explain.

62. Did you ever make up any of your own songs, or make up words to fit an old tune as a joke on somebody, or because of something happening in the community? Explain.

63. Was there a band in your community? When was it started? Who started it? How long did it continue? How many were in it? Who was bandmaster? What instruments were included?

Tell what you remember of its activities; how often practice was held, where, if members had uniforms, what events the band played for.
64. Has anyone from your community become well known or famous in the musical world? Give names and dates and places of public appearances.

65. Is music as important or less important in your community now as compared with the early days? What is the reason for this change?

HOBBIES AND SPECIAL INTERESTS.

66. Do you have any "collections", such as stamps, stones, paintings, signatures, arrowheads, etc.? 

Give details of this collection, telling when you started it, how you became interested in it, any outstanding events connected with it, and a description of the collection.

67. Did you make notes of the weather, time of arrival of birds, blooming time of trees, etc.? Explain.

68. Describe other hobbies or special interests of yours not already mentioned.

69. Is there anyone in your community who is well-known for any of these hobbies, or for others such as photography, bird-watching, etc.?

GENERAL

70. Describe any outstanding features or incidents of social life, games, entertainment, sports, reading, music of pioneer days, not already mentioned. (Use back of page, or extra sheets if necessary).
10.

64. Has anyone from your community become well known or famous in the musical world? Give names and dates and places of public appearances.

65. In what ways important or less important in your community now as compared with the early days? What is the reason for this change?

HOBBIESTS AND SPECIAL INTERESTS:

66. Do you have any "collections", such as stamps, stones, paintings, signatures, arrowheads, etc.? If so, give details of this collection, telling when you started it, how you became interested in it, any outstanding events connected with it, and a description of the collection.

67. Did you make notes of the weather, time of arrival of birds, blooming time of flowers, etc.? Explain.

68. Describe other hobbies or special interests of yours not already mentioned.

69. Is there anyone in your community who is well-known for any of these hobbies, or for others such as photography, bird-watching, etc.?

GENERAL

70. Describe any outstanding features or incidents of social life, games, entertainments, sports, reading, music of pioneer days; not already mentioned.

(use back of page, or extra sheets if necessary)
Oxford.
